text: highway 1 in southeastern Louisiana hugs
Bayou Lafourche
where for generations Cajun families
have made their living from its
slow-moving fresh water but as the land
disappears before their eyes the result
of coastal erosion a centuries-old
culture struggles to stay afloat
this is Susan Sol nee reporter for The
New York Times in 1941 writers for the
Louisiana WPA Travel Guide described
this area an hour south of New Orleans
as a thriving strip of boomtowns made
vibrant by the fish and shrimping
industry
I spent the week along the bayou driving
south from Golden Meadow to Grand Isle
on the Gulf of Mexico looking for signs
about how the landscape and culture had
fared since the guides publication
on my first day I met elf a brunet and
his family almost every day his wife
veena may makes lunch with fish
shellfish and their sons catching the
Bayou or the Gulf that was caught Monday
yeah this be here with Connie put on
this day the kids and grandkids joined
them for fried trout and cuvee young you
might notice we like our fingers to the
Bernays are typical Cajuns as is obvious
from their dialect cuisine and
close-knit family they've lived here all
their lives I was maybe 8 9 10 years old
we we swim in the volume boats traveling
south were familiar sight they would
haul food they throw apples and oranges
at the kids along the bike you see WPA
guide describes bustling activity on the
bayou at this time houseboats lined the
banks and shrimpers and fishermen
shouted to each other in Cajun French
but the Bayou is quieter now and there
are other differences as saltwater from
the Gulf of Mexico pushes into the
marshes and the Bayou from the highway
to the Bayou oh yeah there was much more
Lancer and now then lion is through the
years yeah
the impact of coastal erosion in the
area is unmistakable as the coast is
disappearing at a rate that fluctuates
but is estimated to be between 12 to
more than 20 square miles a year
the Brunei is 23 year old granddaughter
Francine sees the effects well when my
grandfather was young you know they'd
have a little walkway from the roadside
out you know 40 50 yards into the marsh
where they are they're camp out on
parlons and I mean as far as you can see
now there's nothing anymore Marsh is
noted for their wild animal life and
exotic flowers and the wpa guide have
been washed away and replaced by open
water so-called ghost trees or
everywhere fragments of the tremendous
oaks that grew here years ago of drowned
the ecological changes have impacted the
shrimping and fishing industries I spoke
with the sugar
Richard Hogan about some of his troubles
shrimp don't have the place to hold up
in the marshes like they used to and we
had longer seasons where now with our
marshlands deteriorating the shrimp size
has been real small this year and
is remaining small all year
my shrimp will spend most of their money
in this job so in fishing that's by hand
the old Cajuns talked about the olden
days and the way things used to be
it would forbid the thought French in
school Ron because they were trying to
teach a sailor and if you get caught
talking founded get done if that's how
we'll I'm little l will I then go to
school to market traditional sir
survives through religion
the WPA guy described a vibrant Catholic
legacy that remains visible along the
Bayou the guide noted that people build
shrines and prayed for protection from
floods but today saltwater intrusion is
a greater concern farther south and
leavel population roughly 60 the water
has not even spared the dead watery
tunes are nearly unrecognizable but the
Vista changes in Port Fourchon a town
that didn't even exist at the time of a
WPA guide its docks a launching point
for tankers bringing in oil from
deepwater drilling in the Gulf are one
sign of economic growth and in gated
communities sport fishermen compared
dinner is snapper throat this is a
little bit of a different Delos we don't
waste anything
last stop on the wpa route is Grand Isle
a Gulf beach town alive with a colorful
history of its pirate forefathers the
Brunei's brought France singing there as
a child and she hopes to bring her
grandchildren but the only Road to Grand
Isle like the rest of the land is
sinking it's gonna be impossible to pass
to go to Grand Isle and that's whenever
there's going to be nothing left there's
only so many rocks
